[jdporter], [localtime://2008-12-30 13:35:05]

It seems that as time goes by, more and more off-site tutorials are evaporating, leaving us with broken links. I think we need to agree on some kind of policy on how to handle this.

In the remediation of each broken link event, the first thing to do is decide if the tutorial is worth any effort to resurrect. In many cases, it will be appropriate simply to delete the broken link and move on. return unless worth_the_trouble();

Assuming the tutorial is worth resurrecting, the first thing to try is to see if it has moved, in which case we can simply link to its new location. Failing that, we can try contacting the author to see if there might be some other way we can continue to link to it off site — e.g., if the author is willing and able to re-post it on his server of choice. Failing that, our manifest onus increases considerably.

In the most trivial of cases, the off-site tutorial exists in [http://www.archive.org/|the wayback machine], includes no graphics or other external files, and fits in 64kb. In such a case, the tutorial can be horked from Mr. Wayback and posted here as a tutorial. If it doesn't exist in the WM, and the author can't provide the content, then the tutorial is officially kaput, so we delete the link and get on with life.

Containing graphics (as many tutorials do) and having total content size of over 64kb complicate things for us. If the textual content can be retrieved but the graphics cannot, then we have to decide whether to (a) recreate the graphics, (b) convert the tutorial to succeed without graphics, or (c) kill off the tutorial — a kind of triage. If option (b) is executed, then the tutorial may be posted here (again - only if it fits in the 64kb node size limit).

If a tutorial contains graphics, or is "very large", then often it will be easiest simply to post it on another site ([http://www.perlmonk.org/|perlmonk.org] is probably a good choice) and update the off-site link. Posting such a complicated tutorial on PerlMonks is not entirely out of the question, however, but doing so requires authorization and assistance from the [gods].

I think it would also be a good idea for each [Pedagogues|'gog], whenever you've made short work of a broken link, or are having long work of a broken link, to write about it here. Include such things as the location of the b0rked link (typically a [tutstring]), the scale of the problem, and your expected resolution.

First, thanks to [planetscape] for the great writeup and summary of our discussion. (Sorry for the late post. I, too, blame RL.) I have very little to add, but I want to emphasize a few of the points she already made.

One of my concerns about [Pedagogues] taking requests for tutorials is that it blurs the line between "tutorials section maintenance" and "writes reviews upon request", as the latter could turn into an expectation over time. In addition, I don't want people to have to feel like they have to be a member of [Pedagogues] before they can write a tutorial.

I like the idea of using a directed approach for requesting tutorials. An actively maintained "hot list" of desired tutorial topics would help focus monks' attention on defined problem areas. As prospective tutorials are posted and the section fills out, the topic could be removed from the list and a new one added.

I'm undecided about using a wiki for the list, as it may have a tendency to get buried by additional posts over time (unless, of course, it was a to-do wiki that existed only for the list and not other discussion). A separate node may help keep it more visible. [jdporter]'s idea of a "Tutorials Quest" also crossed my mind, but if we allowed monks to post replies to the list things could get... interesting.
